node.title: FDA delays meeting on COVID vaccine for kids under 5 to review data
node.description: The FDA said the delay allows the agency time to review additional data.
node.content: ["The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has delayed a meeting about a COVID-19 vaccine for children younger than 5 that was originally scheduled to take place next week, raising questions about when they'll be able to get vaccinated against the deadly virus. \u00a0The FDA said it wants to see more data from Pfizer before proceeding.  ", "Kids younger than 5 are the only age group in the U.S. that cannot yet get the vaccine. \u00a0", "The FDA said it is postponing a meeting by an expert panel \u2014 scheduled for February 15 \u2014 to give the agency time to consider additional data, \"allowing for a transparent public discussion as part of our usual scientific and regulatory processes for COVID-19 vaccines.\"", "The panel had been expected to decide if kids under 5 should start getting Pfizer's vaccine in low doses, before a potential third shot. \u00a0", "\"We will provide an update on timing for the advisory committee meeting once we receive additional data on a third dose in this age group from the company's ongoing clinical trial and have an opportunity to complete an updated evaluation,\" the FDA said in a statement.\u00a0", "Pfizer and BioNTech said they expect to data on three vaccine doses in early April.", "This story is developing and will be updated.\u00a0", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
